items.title: amsynth LV2 crashes Ardour when closing plugin GUI
items.body:
### Expected behavior
After having opened the plugin GUI it can be closed again.

### Actual behavior
After having opened the plugin UI Ardour crashes (segmentation fault) when closing the plugin GUI.

### Information

  - Which version of amsynth are you using?
    1.13.2+935+e94c0f2+202312281333
  - Which build of amsynth are you using? (stand-alone application, LV2, DSSI, VST)
    LV2. VST version does not show this behaviour.
  - If using amsynth as a plugin, which host application are you using?
    Ardour 8.2
  - Which operating system & version are you using?
    Debian 12.4 Bookworm

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

  1. Open plugin GUI in Ardour
  2. Close it by either clicking on the x in the top right of the GUI or by clicking on the plugin in the channel strip again

Older versions of amsynth (i.e. 1.10.0) did not show this behaviour.

items.title: Switch from unmaintained lash library to the more active ladish one
items.body:
The lash library, used for session management with jack sound server, is very old (last release in 2009) and unmaintained (no commit in the upstream git since July 2009).
Luckily there is a viable replacement: the Nedko Arnaudov's LADI Session Handler (https://github.com/LADI/ladish). It's a complete rewrite of lash and is much more active (last git commit was in February 2021); it's already used by Carla and Cadence packages from Kxstudio project. It also sports an handy compatibility layer (liblash): all it should be needed to use it is changing the references to lash and its headers in those for the ladish compatibility layer and its headers.

The test patch attached simply does this, without bothering to change "lash" in "ladish" in the messages: it builds and runs OK for simple use on my system...
[amsynth-1.12.4-use-ladish-for-lash.txt](https://github.com/amsynth/amsynth/files/8968508/amsynth-1.12.4-use-ladish-for-lash.txt)

Please consider  the switch...

### Information
  - Which version of amsynth are you using? 1.12.4
  - Which build of amsynth are you using? (stand-alone application, LV2, DSSI, VST) standalone application
  - If using amsynth as a plugin, which host application are you using?

items.title: Changes in specific CC's through midi in are replicated in midi out
items.body:
### Expected behavior

Expected behavior:
Modified CC's are only sent to midi out  in two situations:
1) Change in GUI (so the controller surface/external software is aware of the change).
2) Change of patch using PC command (again to make the controller surface/external software aware of the change).

Which parameters are affected?
Mostly the ones that have "jumps" programed in the GUI; examples:
OSC1 Waveform, OSC2 Waveform, LFO Waveform, OSC2 SYNC TO OSC1, Filter type, etc.



### Actual behavior

The issue:
I discovered that changing some specific CC's through midi in (controller surface/external software), the change in the controller is sent through midi out in AMsynth.

How I discovered it:
One year ago, I started with a project to create a portable two instances synth in a SOC (orange pi PC). The operation was successful (thank you again for the modifications done to correct the bug in the midi channels response) and I was able to use the thing to produce some nice sounds.

The system includes hardware: Orange pi PC, sound card and controller/sequencer surface (Arturia Beatstep) and software: a real time kernel compiled by hand, two instances of the AMSynth (also compiled by hand to have the latest code), jackd (regular package) and also a python parser programed by me to convert delta CC values form the encoders of the controller surface to absolute CC's in AMSynth. This parser also stores de current values for all the CC's, acting as some kind of "man in the middle".

At that time, I was mapping only a couple of CC's and probably I was lucky! Last month I started to control the remaining CC parameters with the surface and so I discovered the issue.

I don't know if this behavior is a feature or a bug. Expected behavior to me is that midi out informs about the changes only in those two named situations: change in GUI (so the controller surface/external software is aware of the change) and PC command to change the the current patch (again, so the controller surface /external software is aware of the change).

May be there are reasons for this, that I don't know/understand...

Would it be possible to implement that behavior to avoid that those CC's are sent through midi out when midi in CC changes are received?

Feel free to request all the information / testing that you need for this.

And thank you in advance.

### Information

  - Which version of amsynth are you using?
 For the testing I'm using 1.12.2. In Soc the most current version available at the moment of building: 1.12.4
  - Which build of amsynth are you using? (stand-alone application, LV2, DSSI, VST)
 Standalone version.
  - If using amsynth as a plugin, which host application are you using?
 Not applies.
  - Which operating system & version are you using?
Ubuntu Studio 21.10 for testing:
Linux ksora 5.13.0-35-generic #40-Ubuntu SMP Mon Mar 7 08:03:10 UTC 2022 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux.

In the soc Armbian 22.02.0-trunk Focal:
Linux tyl 5.10.100-rt62-sunxi #trunk SMP PREEMPT_RT Thu Mar 3 15:17:21 CET 2022 armv7l armv7l armv7l GNU/Linux



### Steps to reproduce the behavior

Run Jack server.
Run one instance of AMSynth with midi connectivity.
Configure midi CC's for some of the CC's in AMSynth: For example OSC1 Waveform and Filter cutoff parameters.
Connect a midi sniffer (gmidimonitor in my case) in theAMSynth  midi out .
Connect a virtual midi keyboard (for example VMPK) able to send CC's. Configure it with both previously stated Controllers.
Connect the VMPK midi out to AMSynth midi in.
Modify the the OSC1 Waveform controller configured in VMPK and see the midi sniffer screen. You can see the CC midi messages going out (not expected behavior).-
Modify the Filter cutoff controller configured in  VMPK and see the midi sniffer screen. You can see nothing (expected behavior)
